SENT.plain: We present the case of a male infant, born prematurely (at 33 weeks gestation) with macrosomia, disproportionate macrocephaly, facial dysmorphism, short penis and a small umbilical defect
He had a large ASD and was ventilated from birth for respiratory distress syndrome
He died at 12 hours of age despite neonatal ITU care
Post-mortem examination showed highly lobulated kidneys with nodules of blastema and foci of hamartomatous change in the medulla
Prominence of pancreatic islet cells and expansion of hepatic portal tracts were also noted
His mother has minor cervical spine abnormalities

We discuss the differential diagnosis and the difficulty in confidently assigning a diagnosis to this patient, as considerable overlap is becoming evident between Simpson-Golabi-Behmel syndrome and Perlman syndrome
